mov.description: Moves a named point to a specific latitude, longitude, and altitude.

arguments.name: point_name
arguments.description: The name of the point to move.

rot.description: Rotates a point to match the orientation implied by the quaternion.

arguments.name: point_name
arguments.description: The name of the point to rotate.

arguments.name: q
arguments.description: A quaternion `[x, y, z, w]` for the rotation.

add_point.description: Adds a new point to the scene.

arguments.name: quaternion
arguments.description: Initial rotation as a quaternion `[x, y, z, w]`.

list_points.description: Lists all points currently in the state.

create_line.description: Creates a line between two points or coordinates.

angle.description: Calculates the angle between two vectors.

findBestQuaternion.description: A wrapper around the `find_best_quaternion_for_desired_attitude` function that simplifies the process of aligning body vectors to target vectors by supporting flexible inputs.

arguments.name: primaryVecArg
arguments.description: The primary body vector. Can be a 3-element array (e.g., [1, 0, 0]) or one of `x`, `y`, or `z`.

arguments.name: secondaryVecArg
arguments.description: The secondary body vector. Can be a 3-element array (e.g., [0, 1, 0]) or one of `x`, `y`, or `z`.

arguments.name: primaryTargetArg
arguments.description: The target vector for the primary body vector. Can be a 3-element array, a line name, or a string in the form `startPoint->endPoint`.

arguments.name: secondaryTargetArg
arguments.description: The target vector for the secondary body vector. Can be a 3-element array, a line name, or a string in the form `startPoint->endPoint`.

frame.description: Returns the local frame vectors of a point.

fetchTLE.description: Fetches the Two-Line Element (TLE) for a satellite using its COSPAR ID.

mov2sat.description: Moves a point to the position of a satellite at a given timestamp.

arguments.name: name
arguments.description: The name of the point to move.

arguments.name: timestamp
arguments.description: The time for which the position is computed.
